  [:displayed]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that are *\"displayed\"* (see
      [isDisplayed]{.title-ref})

- 

  [:empty]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that have an empty content (value or text content)

- 

  [:eq(n)]{.title-ref}

  :   returns the *nth* node based on its global position (0-based
      index);

- 

  [:first]{.title-ref}

  :   returns the first node matching the selector (in the whole
      document)

- 

  [:focusable]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that can be *\"focused\"* (see
      [isFocusable]{.title-ref})

- 

  [:hidden]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that are *not* *\"visible\"* (see
      [isVisible]{.title-ref})

- 

  [:iframe]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that are [\<iframe\>]{.title-ref} elements, and
      returns their [body]{.title-ref} if it is ready

- 

  [:last]{.title-ref}

  :   returns the last node matching the selector (in the whole
      document)

- 

  [:selected]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that are selected (e.g. [\<option\>]{.title-ref}
      elements)

- 

  [:shadow]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that have shadow roots, and returns their shadow
      root

- 

  [:scrollable]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that are scrollable (see [isScrollable]{.title-ref})

- 

  [:value(text)]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes whose value matches the given [text]{.title-ref}

      - given *text* supports regular expression syntax (e.g.
        [:value(/\^foo.+/)]{.title-ref}) and is case-insensitive (unless
        using the [i]{.title-ref} flag at the end of the regex)

- 

  [:visible]{.title-ref}

  :   matches nodes that are *\"visible\"* (see [isVisible]{.title-ref})

### Query & node properties helpers

Hoot provides helpers to query nodes and some of their properties in a
streamlined and elegant way. This can mainly be done through the use of
[queryX]{.title-ref} helpers:

> Returns a list of nodes matching the given [Target]{.title-ref}. This
> function can either be used as a [template literal
> tag](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Template_literals#tagged_templates)
> (only supports string selector without options) or invoked the usual
> way.
>
> The target can be:
>
> > - a [Node]{.title-ref} (or an iterable of nodes), or
> >   [Window]{.title-ref} object;
> > - a [Document]{.title-ref} object (which will be converted to its
> >   body);
> > - a string representing a
> >   `custom selector <hoot/custom-dom-selectors>`{.interpreted-text
> >   role="ref"} (which will be queried from the [root]{.title-ref}
> >   option).
>
> An [options]{.title-ref} object can be specified to filter[^1] the
> results:
>
> > - \`count\`: the exact number of nodes to match (throws an error if
> >   the number of nodes doesn\'t match);
> > - \`displayed\`: whether the nodes must be \"displayed\" (see
> >   [isDisplayed]{.title-ref});
> > - \`focusable\`: whether the nodes must be \"focusable\" (see
> >   [isFocusable]{.title-ref});
> > - \`root\`: the root node to query the selector in (defaults to the
> >   current fixture);
> > - \`visible\`: whether the nodes must be \"visible\" (see
> >   [isVisible]{.title-ref}).
> >   - This option implies [displayed]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Node\[\]]{.title-ref}

> Performs a `queryAll`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} on the given
> [target]{.title-ref} and returns a list of attribute values.
>
> returns
> :   [string\[\]]{.title-ref} list of attribute values

> Performs a `queryAll`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} on the given
> [target]{.title-ref} and returns a list of property values.
>
> returns
> :   [unknown\[\]]{.title-ref} list of property values

> Performs a `queryAll`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} on the given
> [target]{.title-ref} and returns a list of text contents.
>
> returns
> :   [string\[\]]{.title-ref} list of text contents

> Performs a `queryAll`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} on the given
> [target]{.title-ref} and returns a list of values.
>
> returns
> :   [string\[\]]{.title-ref} a list of values

> Performs a `queryOne`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} with the given
> arguments and returns the value of the given [attribute]{.title-ref}
> of the matching node.
>
> returns
> :   [string]{.title-ref} the attribute value

> Performs a `queryAll`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} with the given
> arguments and returns the first result or [null]{.title-ref}.
>
> returns
> :   [Node]{.title-ref} \| [null]{.title-ref} the first matching node

> Performs a `queryAll`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} with the given
> arguments, along with a forced [count: 1]{.title-ref} option to ensure
> only one node matches the given [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> The returned value is a single node instead of a list of nodes.
>
> returns
> :   [Node]{.title-ref} a single node

> Performs a `queryOne`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} with the given
> arguments and returns the *text* of the matching node.
>
> returns
> :   [string]{.title-ref} text of the matching node

> Performs a `queryOne`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} with the given
> arguments and returns the *value* of the matching node.
>
> returns
> :   [string]{.title-ref} value of the matching node

All of the above helpers are synchronous, meaning that they will attempt
to query nodes instantly. Although some use cases require the element to
be awaited for an arbitrary amount of time, unknown in advance due to UI
fetching and rendering complexity.

Hoot provides 2 methods to wait for an element to appear / disappear
within a certain time frame (by default: [200]{.title-ref} milliseconds)
for such cases:

> Combination of `queryAll`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} and
> `waitUntil`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"}: waits for a given
> target to match elements in the DOM and returns the first matching
> node when it appears (or immediately if it is already present).
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Node\>]{.title-ref} containing the first matching node

> Opposite of `waitFor`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} waits for a
> given target to disappear from the DOM.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<number\>]{.title-ref} containing the number of matching
>     nodes

## DOM: interaction helpers

Along with querying elements, it is often required to interact with
them. As such, Hoot provides helpers to simulate various user
interactions on elements.

These can be split into 2 types based on their parameters:
**pointer-based** interaction helpers, and the **other** ones.

### Pointer interaction helpers:

Pointer interaction helpers (such as `click`{.interpreted-text
role="js:meth"} or `drag`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"}) will
simulate actual pointer movements and events on the given target, and on
any previous element the pointer was *supposed* to have been.

> Ensures that the given [Target]{.title-ref} is checked.
>
> If it is not checked, a `click`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} is
> simulated on the input. If the input is still not checked after the
> click, an error is thrown.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> check("input[type=checkbox]"); // Checks the first <input> checkbox element
> ```

> Performs a click sequence on the given [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [pointerdown]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mousedown]{.title-ref}
> > - \[touch\] [touchstart]{.title-ref}
> > - \[target is not active element\] [blur]{.title-ref}
> > - \[target is focusable\] [focus]{.title-ref}
> > - [pointerup]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mouseup]{.title-ref}
> > - \[touch\] [touchend]{.title-ref}
> > - [click]{.title-ref}
> > - [dblclick]{.title-ref} if click is not prevented & current click
> >   count is even
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> click("button"); // Clicks on the first <button> element
> ```

> Performs two `click`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} sequences on
> the given [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> dblclick("button"); // Double-clicks on the first <button> element
> ```

> Starts a drag sequence on the given [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> Returns a set of helper functions to direct the sequence:
>
> > - \`moveTo\`: moves the pointer to the given target;
> > - \`drop\`: drops the dragged element on the given target (if any);
> > - \`cancel\`: cancels the drag sequence.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<DragHelpers\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> drag(".card:first").drop(".card:last"); // Drags the first card onto the last one
>
> drag(".card:first").moveTo(".card:last").drop(); // Same as above
>
> const { cancel, moveTo } = await drag(".card:first"); // Starts the drag sequence
> moveTo(".card:eq(3)"); // Moves the dragged card to the 4th card
> cancel(); // Cancels the drag sequence
> ```

> Performs a hover sequence on the given [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [pointerover]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mouseover]{.title-ref}
> > - [pointerenter]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mouseenter]{.title-ref}
> > - [pointermove]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mousemove]{.title-ref}
> > - \[touch\] [touchmove]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> hover("button"); // Hovers the first <button> element
> ```

> Performs a pointer down on the given [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [pointerdown]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mousedown]{.title-ref}
> > - \[touch\] [touchstart]{.title-ref}
> > - \[target is not active element\] [blur]{.title-ref}
> > - \[target is focusable\] [focus]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> pointerDown("button"); // Focuses to the first <button> element
> ```

> Performs a pointer up on the given [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [pointerup]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mouseup]{.title-ref}
> > - \[touch\] [touchend]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> pointerUp("body"); // Triggers a pointer up on the <body> element
> ```

> Performs a scroll event sequence on the given [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - \[desktop\] [wheel]{.title-ref}
> > - [scroll]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> scroll("body", { y: 0 }); // Scrolls to the top of <body>
> ```

> Sets the given value to the current \"input\[type=range\]\"
> [Target]{.title-ref}.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [pointerdown]{.title-ref}
> > - [input]{.title-ref}
> > - [change]{.title-ref}
> > - [pointerup]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}

> Ensures that the given [Target]{.title-ref} is unchecked.
>
> If it is checked, a `click`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} is
> triggered on the input. If the input is still checked after the click,
> an error is thrown.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> uncheck("input[type=checkbox]"); // Unchecks the first <input> checkbox element
> ```

### Other interaction helpers:

Other interaction helpers will not have a [target]{.title-ref}
parameter. It is not needed, since pressing keys on a keyboard (for
example) is done on the current *active element*.

> Clears the value of the current *active element*.
>
> This is done using the following sequence:
>
> > - pressing [\"Control\"]{.title-ref} & [\"A\"]{.title-ref} to select
> >   the whole value;
> > - pressing [\"Backspace\"]{.title-ref} to delete the value;
> > - (optional) triggering a [\"change\"]{.title-ref} event by pressing
> >   [\"Enter\"]{.title-ref}.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> clear(); // Clears the value of the current active element
> ```

> Combination of `clear`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} and
> `fill`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"}:
>
> > - first, clears the input value (if any)
> > - then fills the input with the given value
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> fill("foo"); // Types "foo" in the active element
> edit("Hello World"); // Replaces "foo" by "Hello World"
> ```

> Fills the current *active element* with the given [value]{.title-ref}.
> This helper is intended for [\<input\>]{.title-ref} and
> [\<textarea\>]{.title-ref} elements, with the exception of
> [\"checkbox\"]{.title-ref} and [\"radio\"]{.title-ref} types, which
> should be selected using the [check]{.title-ref} helper.
>
> If the target is an editable input, its string [value]{.title-ref}
> will be input one character at a time, each generating its
> corresponding keyboard event sequence. This behavior can be overridden
> by passing the [instantly]{.title-ref} option, which will instead
> simulate a [control]{.title-ref} + [v]{.title-ref} keyboard sequence,
> resulting in the whole text being pasted.
>
> Note that the given value is appended to the current value of the
> element.
>
> If the active element is a [\<input type=\"file\"/\>]{.title-ref}, the
> [value]{.title-ref} should be a [File]{.title-ref}/list of
> [File]{.title-ref} object(s).
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> fill("Hello World"); // Types "Hello World" in the active element
> fill("Hello World", { instantly: true }); // Pastes "Hello World" in the active element
> fill(new File(["Hello World"], "hello.txt")); // Uploads a file named "hello.txt" with "Hello World" as content
> ```

> Performs a key down sequence on the current *active element*.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [keydown]{.title-ref}
>
> Additional actions will be performed depending on the key pressed:
>
> > - \`Tab\`: focus next (or previous with [shift]{.title-ref})
> >   focusable element;
> > - \`c\`: copy current selection to clipboard;
> > - \`v\`: paste current clipboard content to current element;
> > - \`Enter\`: submit the form if the target is a [\<button
> >   type=\"button\"\>]{.title-ref} or a [\<form\>]{.title-ref}
> >   element, or trigger a [change]{.title-ref} event on the target if
> >   it is an [\<input\>]{.title-ref} element;
> > - \`Space\`: trigger a [click]{.title-ref} event on the target if it
> >   is an [\<input type=\"checkbox\"\>]{.title-ref} element.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> keyDown(" "); // Space key
> ```

> Performs a key up sequence on the current *active element*.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [keyup]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> keyUp("Enter");
> ```

> Performs a leave sequence on the current [Window]{.title-ref}.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [pointermove]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mousemove]{.title-ref}
> > - \[touch\] [touchmove]{.title-ref}
> > - [pointerout]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mouseout]{.title-ref}
> > - [pointerleave]{.title-ref}
> > - \[desktop\] [mouseleave]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> leave("button"); // Moves out of <button>
> ```

> Performs a keyboard event sequence on the current *active element*.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [keydown]{.title-ref}
> > - [keyup]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> pointerDown("button[type=submit]"); // Moves focus to <button>
> keyDown("Enter"); // Submits the form
>
> keyDown("Shift+Tab"); // Focuses previous focusable element
>
> keyDown(["ctrl", "v"]); // Pastes current clipboard content
> ```

> Performs a resize event sequence on the current [Window]{.title-ref}.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [resize]{.title-ref}
>
> The target will be resized to the given dimensions, enforced by
> [!important]{.title-ref} style attributes.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> resize("body", { width: 1000, height: 500 }); // Resizes <body> to 1000x500
> ```

> Performs a selection event sequence on the current active element.
> This helper is intended for [\<select\>]{.title-ref} elements only.
>
> The event sequence is as follows:
>
> > - [change]{.title-ref}
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}
>
> ``` javascript
> click("select[name=country]"); // Focuses <select> element
> select("belgium"); // Selects the <option value="belgium"> element
> ```

> Gives the given [File]{.title-ref} list to the current file input.
> This helper only works if a file input has been previously interacted
> with (by clicking on it).
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}

> Triggers a \"beforeunload\" event on the current [Window]{.title-ref}.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<Event\[\]\>]{.title-ref}

## Mocks

By default, a lot of low-level features are mocked by Hoot:
[clipboard]{.title-ref}, [fetch]{.title-ref},
[localStorage]{.title-ref}, etc. These mocks are intended to not produce
any side-effect that would disturb the test runner or the context of
other tests, while still providing the same interface to allow tests to
rely on these features seamlessly.

There is also a need (most of the time) to force actions on these
features or change their behavior for a test, so there exist helpers to
interact with these mocked features. The following sections will list
the main mocked features and the means to interact with them.

### Time

Most asynchronous features are mocked: \"timers\"
([setTimeout]{.title-ref}, [setInterval]{.title-ref} and
[requestAnimationFrame]{.title-ref}), [Date]{.title-ref} and
[performance]{.title-ref} all behave normally, but can be canceled or
sped-up manually to considerably shorten the actual duration of tests.
For example: all \"timers\" are canceled at the end of each test to
avoid side-effects for the next one.

> :::: important
> ::: title
> Important
> :::
>
> There are 2 main timing behaviors that are *NOT* mocked:
>
> - [Promise]{.title-ref} objects and related API;
> - OWL\'s timer functions: to wait for OWL rendering functions, you\'ll
>   have to resort to the [animationFrame]{.title-ref} helper.
> ::::

#### Related helpers

> Calls [advanceTime]{.title-ref} with the duration it would take for a
> given [frameCount]{.title-ref} amount of frames to have rendered in
> the UI (i.e. (1000 / current FPS) x frame count).

> Advances the current time by the given amount of milliseconds. This
> will affect all timeouts, intervals, animations and date objects.
>
> It returns a promise resolved after all related callbacks have been
> executed.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<number\>]{.title-ref} time consumed by timers (in ms)

> Returns a promise resolved after the next animation frame, typically
> allowing Owl components to render.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<void\>]{.title-ref}

> Cancels all current timeouts, intervals and animations.

> Returns a promise resolved after a given amount of milliseconds
> (default to [0]{.title-ref}).
>
> ``` javascript
> await delay(1000); // waits for 1 second
> ```
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<void\>]{.title-ref}

> Returns a promise resolved after the next microtask tick.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<void\>]{.title-ref}

> Mocks the current date and time, and also the time zone if any.
>
> Date can either be an object describing the date and time to mock, or
> a string in SQL or ISO format (time and millisecond values can be
> omitted). See `mockTimeZone`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"} for the
> time zone params.
>
> ``` javascript
> mockDate("2023-12-25T20:45:00"); // 2023-12-25 20:45:00 UTC
> mockDate({ year: 2023, month: 12, day: 25, hour: 20, minute: 45 }); // same as above
> mockDate("2019-02-11 09:30:00.001", +2);
> ```

> Mocks the current time zone.
>
> Time zone can either be a locale, a time zone or an offset.
>
> Returns a function restoring the default zone.
>
> ``` javascript
> mockTimeZone(+1); // UTC + 1
> mockTimeZone("Europe/Brussels"); // UTC + 1 (or UTC + 2 in summer)
> mockTimeZone("ja-JP"); // UTC + 9
> ```

> Calculates the amount of time needed to run all current timeouts,
> intervals and animations, and then advances the current time by that
> amount.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<void\>]{.title-ref}

> Sets the current frame rate (in fps) used by animation frames (default
> to 60fps).

> Returns a promise resolved after the next task tick.
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<void\>]{.title-ref}

> Returns a promise fulfilled when the given [predicate]{.title-ref}
> returns a truthy value, with the value of the promise being the return
> value of the [predicate]{.title-ref}.
>
> The [predicate]{.title-ref} is run once initially and then each time
> the DOM is mutated (see [observe]{.title-ref} for more information).
>
> The promise automatically rejects after a given [timeout]{.title-ref}
> (defaults to 5 seconds).
>
> returns
> :   [Promise\<unknown\>]{.title-ref} promise with the return value of
>     the predicate

### Network

In general, we don\'t want to perform actual network calls in tests. To
ensure this, all calls to [fetch]{.title-ref} and
[XMLHttpRequest]{.title-ref} have been re-routed to a function given to
`mockFetch`{.interpreted-text role="js:meth"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

In Odoo, this is generally implicitly handled by a
`MockServer <mock-server/configuration>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
which is spawned by the mock environment, i.e. any time a component is
rendered using the
`mountWithCleanup <web-test-helpers/components>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} helper.
::::

#### Related helpers

> Mocks the fetch function by replacing it with a given
> [fetchFn]{.title-ref}.
>
> The return value of [fetchFn]{.title-ref} is used as the response of
> the mocked fetch, or wrapped in a [MockResponse]{.title-ref} object if
> it does not meet the required format.
>
> ``` javascript
> mockFetch((input, init) => {
>     if (input === "/../web_search_read") {
>         return { records: [{ id: 3, name: "john" }] };
>     }
>     // ...
> });
> mockFetch((input, init) => {
>     if (input === "/translations") {
>         const translations = {
>             "Hello, world!": "Bonjour, monde !",
>             // ...
>         };
>         return new Response(JSON.stringify(translations));
>     }
> });
> ```

> Activates mock WebSocket classe:
>
> > - websocket connections will be handled by
> >   [window.fetch]{.title-ref} (see `mockFetch`{.interpreted-text
> >   role="js:meth"});
> > - the [onWebSocketConnected]{.title-ref} callback will be called
> >   after a websocket has been created.

> Activates mock [Worker]{.title-ref} and [SharedWorker]{.title-ref}
> classes:
>
> > - actual code fetched by worker URLs will then be handled by
> >   [window.fetch]{.title-ref} (see `mockFetch`{.interpreted-text
> >   role="js:meth"});
> > - the [onWorkerConnected]{.title-ref} callback will be called after
> >   a worker has been created.

### Notable global features

The following features may not have any specific mocked feature added,
but they do work as expected without changing the actual properties they
were meant to:

- [Document](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document)

  > Both [title]{.title-ref} and [cookie]{.title-ref} can be set and
  > read without changing the actual properties of the current document.

- [History](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/History)

  > The [history]{.title-ref} API is mocked and bound to the
  > [mockLocation]{.title-ref} object to return the same values and
  > provide consistency.

- [Location](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Location)

  > Hoot returns a [mockLocation]{.title-ref} object to use instead of
  > [window.location]{.title-ref}, but this relies on the use of an
  > indirection in the actual production code.
  >
  > :::: important
  > ::: title
  > Important
  > :::
  >
  > This feature will only work if an indirection is set between
  > production code and calls to [window.location]{.title-ref}. In Odoo,
  > it works because the [\@web/core/browser]{.title-ref} module
  > provides such an indirection, and that module is mocked in test
  > environments to redirect to the [mockLocation]{.title-ref} object.
  > ::::

- [Navigator](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator)

  > Most used navigator features, such as the [clipboard]{.title-ref}
  > API and [userAgent]{.title-ref}, have been mocked to hijack their
  > actual behaviors. Its [permissions]{.title-ref} object has been
  > bound to a global mock of the permissions API.

- [Notification](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Notification)

  > Notifications have been mocked, with the \"notification\"
  > permissions bound to the global mocked permissions API.

- [Permissions](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Permissions_API)

  > Permissions can enable or disable other APIs by being given the
  > [\"granted\"]{.title-ref} or [\"denied\"]{.title-ref} statuses. This
  > can be done through the [mockPermission]{.title-ref} helper.

- [Storage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Storage)

  > [localStorage]{.title-ref} and [sessionStorage]{.title-ref} both
  > point to \"virtual\" storages.

- [Touch](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Touch_events)

  > Touch features can be force-activated or deactivated globally for a
  > given test/suite using the `mockTouch`{.interpreted-text
  > role="js:meth"} helper. It will mock both the presence of touch
  > handlers like [ontouchstart]{.title-ref} on window, as well as the
  > [\"pointer\"]{.title-ref} media being set to [fine]{.title-ref} or
  > [coarse]{.title-ref}.

#### Related helpers

> Sets the given value for the given permission. This allows to enable
> or prevent certain APIs (see the [Permissions
> API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Permissions_API)).
>
> ``` javascript
> // Prevents the whole notification API from working
> mockPermission("notifications", "denied");
> ```

> Toggles touch features on or off in the current [Window]{.title-ref}.

[^1]: these filters (except for [count]{.title-ref} and
    [root]{.title-ref}) achieve the same result as using their homonym
    pseudo-classes on the final group of the given selector string,
    e.g.:

    ``` javascript
    // These 2 will return the same result
    queryAll`ul > li:visible`;
    queryAll("ul > li", { visible: true });
    ```




--- SOURCE: developer/reference/frontend/unit_testing/mock_server.md ---

# Mock server

## Rationale

Test cases can range in complexity; from testing the return value of a
simple helper function, to rendering an entire webclient to simulate
interactions across several components/services.

In the latter cases, many interactions will trigger server requests,
without which the components or features will stop functioning properly.
However, it is important that these requests *do not* land on the actual
server, as they could affect the database, which is definitely not
something a test should be doing.

To overcome this, each request should be intercepted and replaced by a
function emulating actual server responses with test (i.e. fake) data.

Since some of these requests are very common (e.g. ORM calls, such as
[web_search_read]{.title-ref} or [web_save]{.title-ref}, or other
methods such as [get_views]{.title-ref}), a mock server has been
implemented by default for every test that spawns an
`env (Odoo environment)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}[^1].

These mock servers act independently for each test, can be configured
separately, and provide out of the box helpers for the most used routes
in Odoo.

## Overview

A mock server is actually quite simple in itself: it is an object
containing a *collection* of all defined mock models, and a *mapping*
between routes and callbacks returning the test data.

The mock models themselves hold most of the CRUD logic, as well as the
data used to simulate server records.

Once a mock server starts, it hijacks *all* server requests, and for
each of them it will check in its *mapping* whether one of its
registered routes matches the requested URL. The most notable example of
its pre-defined routes is [/web/dataset/call_kw]{.title-ref}, which is
responsible for calling an ORM method on the appropriate mock model.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Like most test helpers not provided by Hoot, mock server-related helpers
and classes can be found in the
[\"@web/../tests/web_test_helpers\"]{.title-ref} module.
::::

## Configuration {#mock-server/configuration}

By default, a mock server is *\"empty\"*, meaning that it has no defined
mock model.

This does not mean that it is useless though, as it will already handle
a few pre-defined routes, such as the ones responsible for fetching
[menus]{.title-ref} and [translations]{.title-ref}, which are spawned by
`services <../services>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} as soon as an
[env]{.title-ref} is spawned.

But this means that ORM methods will fail, as the model that they target
has not been defined yet.

To create and define a mock model, you need 2 things:

- a [class]{.title-ref} extending the [models.Model]{.title-ref} class;

  > - special keys prefixed with a [\_]{.title-ref} act as metadata
  >   holders, like in Python (e.g. [\_name]{.title-ref},
  >   [\_order]{.title-ref}, [\_description]{.title-ref}, etc.)[^2][^3];
  > - [\_records]{.title-ref} holds the list of objects representing
  >   fake record data;
  > - [\_views]{.title-ref} can be a mapping of view types and XML
  >   arches;
  > - other [public class
  >   fields](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes/Public_class_fields)
  >   will be interpreted as fields (by calling the appropriate method
  >   from [fields]{.title-ref});
  > - model-specific methods (such as [has_group]{.title-ref} for
  >   [\"res.users\"]{.title-ref}) can also be defined here.

- calling [defineModels]{.title-ref} with the class defined above.

Here is a basic example of a simple, fake, [\"res.partner\"]{.title-ref}
model:

``` javascript
import { defineModels, fields, models } from "@web/../tests/web_test_helpers";

class ResPartner extends models.Model {
    _name = "res.partner";

    name = fields.Char({ required: true );

    _records = [
        { name: "Mitchel Admin" },
    ];

    _views = {
        form: /* xml */`
            <form>
                <field name="name" />
            </form>
        `,
        list: /* xml */`
            <list>
                <field name="display_name" />
            </list>
        `,
    };
}

defineModels({ ResPartner });
```

This code will make these data available for *all* tests in the current
test file. Of course, defining a class and calling
[defineModels]{.title-ref} can also be done from *within* a given test
to limit the scope of that model to the current test.

Other methods such as [defineMenus]{.title-ref},
[defineActions]{.title-ref} or [defineParams]{.title-ref} can also be
used to configure the current mock server. Most of their API is quite
straightforward (i.e. they receive JSON-like descriptions of menus,
actions, etc.).

### Mock models: requests

Many test cases only require one or a few mock models to work. But
sometimes, it is either too bothersome to implement the mocking logic
within a model, or a *route* (i.e. server request URL) is simply not
associated to a Python model at all.

In such cases, the [onRpc]{.title-ref} method is to be called, to
associate a route or an ORM method to a callback.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Multiple [onRpc]{.title-ref} calls can be associated to the same route /
ORM method; in which case they will be called sequentially from last to
first defined. Returning a *non-null-or-undefined* value will interrupt
the current chain, and return that value as final result of the server
request.
::::

It can be used in 4 different ways:

#### \`onRpc\`: with a route ([\"/\"]{.title-ref})

When the first argument is a [string]{.title-ref} starting with a
[\"/\"]{.title-ref}, the callback is expected to be a *route* callback,
receiving a [Request\_]{.title-ref} object:

``` javascript
onRpc("/route/to/test", async (request) => {
    const { ids }  = await request.json();
    expect.step(ids);
    return {};
});
```

By default, the return value of these callbacks are wrapped within the
[body]{.title-ref} of a mock [Response\_]{.title-ref} object.

This is fine for most use-cases, but sometimes the callback needs to
respond with a [Response\_]{.title-ref} object with custom
[status]{.title-ref} or [headers]{.title-ref}.

In such cases, an *optional* dictionary can be passed as a 3rd argument
to specify whether the callback is to be considered *\"pure\"*, meaning
that its return value should be returned as-is to the server caller:

``` javascript
onRpc(
    "/not/found",
    () => new Response("{}", { status: 404 }),
    { pure: true }
);
```

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Using *\"pure\"* request callbacks can also be used to return anything
else than a [Response\_]{.title-ref} object, in which case the returned
value will still be wrapped in the body of a mock
[Response\_]{.title-ref} to comply with the [fetch\_]{.title-ref} /
[XMLHttpRequest\_]{.title-ref} APIs.
::::

#### \`onRpc\`: with method name(s)

When the first argument is a [string]{.title-ref} *NOT* starting with a
[\"/\"]{.title-ref} or a list of [strings]{.title-ref}, the callback is
expected to be an ORM callback, only called when the request\'s
[method]{.title-ref} matches the one given as argument.

The callback will receive an object containing:

- the *spread* [params]{.title-ref} value contained in the request body
  (typically: [args]{.title-ref}, [kwargs]{.title-ref},
  [model]{.title-ref} and [method]{.title-ref});
- a [parent()]{.title-ref} function, which when invoked will call the
  defined ORM callback *preceding* this one;
- a [route]{.title-ref} key, containing the [pathname]{.title-ref} of
  the request (typically: [/web/dataset/call_kw]{.title-ref});
- the [request]{.title-ref} object.

``` javascript
onRpc("web_read", async ({ args, parent }) => {
    const result = parent();
    expect.step(args[0]); // Contains the list of IDs
    result.some_meta_data = { foo: "bar" };
    return result;
});
```

#### \`onRpc\`: with model name(s) AND method name(s)

When:

- the first argument is a [string]{.title-ref} *NOT* starting with a
  [\"/\"]{.title-ref} or a list of [strings]{.title-ref};
- the second argument is also a [string]{.title-ref} or a list of
  [strings]{.title-ref};

Then the callback is expected to be an ORM callback, only called when
the request\'s [method]{.title-ref} *AND* [model]{.title-ref} match the
ones given in the arguments.

This works just the same as the above shape, with an added
[model]{.title-ref} filter:

``` javascript
onRpc("web_read", "res.partner", ({ args }) => {
    expect.step(args[0]);
});
```

#### \`onRpc\`: for *every* ORM method/model

When the *only* argument is a callback, it is expected to be an ORM
callback to be called for *every* ORM call:

``` javascript
onRpc(({ method }) => {
    expect.step(method); // Will step every ORM method call on every model
});
```

### Mock models: fields

Model fields can be declared in 2 ways:

- as [public class
  fields](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes/Public_class_fields);

- under the [\_fields]{.title-ref} special key. For example:

  > ``` javascript
  > test("test view with date fields", async () => {
  >     // `_fields` can be assigned over, or extended directly.
  >     ResPartner._fields.date = fields.Date({ string: "Registration date" });
  > });
  > ```

Field constructors can take a parameters dictionary to dictate their
behaviour. It will be required for some of them, like relational fields,
which need a [relation]{.title-ref} property to work correctly.

There are limits to what can be done with a mock field compared to an
actual Python server field, but expect the most basic properties to be
supported: [readonly]{.title-ref}, [required]{.title-ref},
[string]{.title-ref}, etc.

[compute]{.title-ref} and [related]{.title-ref} do work for the most
basic use-cases, but do not expect them to function reliably as they
would on the actual server.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

There are 4 default fields pre-defined for each created model:
[id]{.title-ref}, [display_name]{.title-ref}, [created_at]{.title-ref}
and [updated_at]{.title-ref}. They match their server-side counterpart
in their behaviour (e.g. [id]{.title-ref} is incremental and
[display_name]{.title-ref} has a [compute]{.title-ref} function similar
to its server counterpart), and can be overridden if needed.
::::

### Mock models: records

Model records are generated based on each object contained in the
[\_records]{.title-ref} special key *when the model is loaded*. They are
validated based on the fields available on the current models; if a
property does not match a field defined on the model, an error is
thrown.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

[\_records]{.title-ref} *cannot* be altered *after* the model has been
loaded, i.e. after the mock server has started. This key is only used to
generate initial records. If records should be added *after* model
creation, do it either form the available components in the UI, or
through direct ORM calls on the mock server instance.
::::

### Mock models: views

Since actual views need an [\"ir.ui.view\"]{.title-ref} model to be
declared, mock models use a simplified *mapping* to provide view arches.

The [\_view]{.title-ref} special key is a dictionary, with its *keys*
being view types, optionally accompanied by a view ID, and its *values*
being the XML arch string representation.

By default, view IDs are [false]{.title-ref}, but can be specified
explicitly with a comma-separated key combining the view type and its
ID:

``` javascript
// Will simulate a list view with no ID (false).
ResPartner._views.list = /* xml */ `
    <list>
        <field name="display_name" />
    </list>
`;

// Will simulate a form view with ID 418.
ResPartner._views["form,418"] = /* xml */ `
    <form>
        <field name="name" />
        <field name="date" />
    </form>
`;
```

## Spawning a mock server {#mock-server/spawning}

Just like in most cases, only one server can be active for a given test.

As mentioned above, creating an [env]{.title-ref} will automatically
deploy a mock server.

This means that all of these methods will *also* create a mock server,
since they do create an \`env\`:

- `makeMockEnv <web-test-helpers/environment>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"};
- `mountWithCleanup <web-test-helpers/components>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"} (calling
  `makeMockEnv <web-test-helpers/environment>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"});
- `mountView <web-test-helpers/views>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}
  (calling
  `mountWithCleanup <web-test-helpers/components>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}).

However, some low-level features may require to spawn a mock server
*without* an environment. For that purpose, a
[makeMockServer]{.title-ref} helper can be called separately to initiate
a mock server.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

[makeMockServer]{.title-ref} should *only* be used by low-level
features, such as testing the [rpc]{.title-ref} function without the
environment. It is not meant to be used as a means to retrieve the
current mock server instance. For that purpose, refer to
`MockServer.current <mock-server/interacting>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}.
::::

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

It is to be noted that subsequent calls to [makeMockServer]{.title-ref}
after a mock server has been started are simply ignored.
::::

## Interacting with the server {#mock-server/interacting}

While most of the server interactions are expected to be done directly
or indirectly by production code spawned in the test case, it is
sometimes meaningful to bypass the UI and call the mock server directly
(e.g. to simulate that another user, somewhere else, somehow, has
altered the database).

This can be done by retrieving the [MockServer.current]{.title-ref}
static property containing the current mock server instance (only after
initialization):

``` javascript
// Most common ORM methods are provided out of the box by server models,
// and are synchronous. Although, be careful that this will NOT trigger a
// UI re-render, and will ONLY affect the (fake) database.
const ids = MockServer.env["res.partner"].create([
    { name: "foo" },
    { name: "bar" },
]);
```

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

[MockServer.env]{.title-ref} is just a shortcut to
[MockServer.current.env]{.title-ref}.
::::

[^1]: A mock server is needed as soon as an environment is spawned
    because some `services <../services>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
    do send server requests as soon as they start.

[^2]: Only a subset of these special keys will have an actual effect.
    For example, [\_inherit]{.title-ref} will not work as intended,
    prefer standard class extension.

[^3]: These can be altered by each test without thinking about cleaning
    up: any change performed on a special key will be reverted at the
    end of a test.




--- SOURCE: developer/reference/frontend/unit_testing/web_helpers.md ---

# Web test helpers

## Overview

After the `"@odoo/hoot" <./hoot>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} module,
the second most-solicited module in test files should be
[\"@web/../tests/web_test_helpers\"]{.title-ref}.

This module contains all the helpers that combine the low-level helpers
provided by Hoot, with all the most common features that are used in
tests in Odoo.

These helpers are many, and this section of the documentation will only
highlight the most common ones, and the way they interact with one
another.

For a full list of available helpers, you may refer to the
[web_test_helpers
file]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/web_test_helpers.js).

## Mock environment {#web-test-helpers/environment}

The [makeMockEnv]{.title-ref} helper is the lowest helper that can spawn
an [env]{.title-ref}.

It will take care of

- creating the [env]{.title-ref} object itself, pre-configured with all
  the required properties for the proper functioning of web components,
  such as [getTemplate]{.title-ref} or [translateFn]{.title-ref};
- spawning a [MockServer]{.title-ref} (if one did not exist already for
  that test);
- starting all registered `services <../services>`{.interpreted-text
  role="doc"}, and awaiting until they are all ready;
- initiating other features that are not tied to a service, such as the
  web [router]{.title-ref};
- guaranteeing the teardown of all the features in its setup at the end
  of the test.

This method is great for testing low-level features, such as
`services <../services>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} that are not tied
to a
[Component](https://github.com/odoo/owl/blob/master/doc/reference/component.md):

``` javascript
// Can be further configured, but is already packed with all the necessary stuff
const env = await makeMockEnv();

expect(env.isSmall).toBe(false);
```

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Like `makeMockServer <mock-server/spawning>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, only one [env]{.title-ref} can be active for a given test.
It is not necessary to call [makeMockEnv]{.title-ref} manually to
retrieve the current environment instance; the [getMockEnv]{.title-ref}
helper can be called instead.
::::

::: example
- [DateTime input
  tests]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/core/components/datetime/datetime_input.test.js)
- [Name service
  tests]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/core/name_service.test.js)
:::

## Mounting components {#web-test-helpers/components}

Instantiating and appending
[components](https://github.com/odoo/owl/blob/master/doc/reference/component.md)
to the DOM is meant to be easy, through the use of the
[mountWithCleanup]{.title-ref} helper. It will prepare an
[env]{.title-ref} internally (if one does not exist yet), which in turn
also makes sure that a [MockServer]{.title-ref} is running.

It takes a [Component]{.title-ref} class as its first argument, and an
*optional* parameters second argument, used to specify
[props]{.title-ref} or a custom \`target\`:

``` javascript
await mountWithCleanup(Checkbox, {
    props: {
        value: false
    },
});
```

This helper will return the active [Component]{.title-ref} instance.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

It is generally *ill-advised* to retrieve the [Component]{.title-ref}
instance to directly interact with it or to perform assertions on its
internal variables. The only \"accepted\" use cases are when the
[Component]{.title-ref} is displaying hard-to-retrieve information in
the DOM, such as graphs in a
[canvas](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Canvas_API).
For most cases, it is highly preferred to query derived information in
the DOM.
::::

::: example
- [Checkbox
  tests]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/core/checkbox.test.js)
- [Popover
  tests]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/core/popover/popover.test.js)
- [DateTimePicker
  tests]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/core/components/datetime/datetime_picker.test.js)
:::

## Mounting views {#web-test-helpers/views}

Mounting a view is simply a matter of using
`mountWithCleanup <web-test-helpers/components>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"} with the
[View](%7BGITHUB_PATH%7D/addons/web/static/src/views/view.js) component
and the correct properties.

For that purpose, web test helpers export a [mountView]{.title-ref}
helper, taking a parameters object determining the view
[type]{.title-ref}, [resModel]{.title-ref}, and other optional
properties such as an XML \`arch\`:

``` javascript
// Resolves when the view is fully ready
await mountView({
    type: "list",
    resModel: "res.partner",
    arch: /* xml */ `
        <list>
            <field name="display_name" />
        </list>
    `,
});
```

Like the previous helpers on top of which [mountView]{.title-ref} is
built, it will ensure that both an [env]{.title-ref} and a
[MockServer]{.title-ref} are running for the current test.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Like `mountWithCleanup <web-test-helpers/components>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, it is *NOT* recommended to retrieve the returned
[View](%7BGITHUB_PATH%7D/addons/web/static/src/views/view.js) component
instance. It can however be done, for cases like the [Graph
view]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/src/views/graph/graph_view.js).
::::

::: example
- [Calendar view
  tests]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/views/calendar/calendar_view.test.js)
- [Graph view
  tests]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/views/graph/graph_view.test.js)
- [Kanban view
  tests]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/views/kanban/kanban_view.test.js)
:::

## Interacting with components

Hoot provides helpers to interact with the DOM (e.g.
[click]{.title-ref}, [press]{.title-ref}, etc.). However, these helpers
present 2 issues when interacting with more complex components:

1.  helpers try to interact instantly, while sometimes the element has
    yet to be appended to the document (in an unknown amount of time);
2.  helpers only wait a single micro-task tick per dispatched event,
    while most Owl-based UIs take at least a full animation frame to
    update.

``` javascript
// Edit record name
await click(".o_field_widget[name=name]");
await edit("Gaston Lagaffe");

// Potential error 1: button may not be in the DOM yet
await click(".btn:contains(Save)");

// Potential error 2: view is not yet updated
expect(".o_field_widget[name=name]").toHaveText("Gaston Lagaffe");
```

With these constraints in mind, web test helpers provide the
[contains]{.title-ref} helper:

``` javascript
// Combines 'click' + 'edit' + 'animationFrame' calls
await contains(".o_field_widget[name=name]").edit("Gaston Lagaffe");
// Waits for (at least) a full animation frame after the click
await contains(".btn:contains(Save)").click();
expect(".o_field_widget[name=name]").toHaveText("Gaston Lagaffe");
```

This approach, while seemingly drifting a bit further away from the
concept of \"unit testing\", is still a nice and convenient way to test
more complex units such as
[views](%7BGITHUB_PATH%7D/addons/web/static/src/views/view.js), the
[WebClient]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/src/webclient/webclient.js),
or interactions between couples of
`services <../services>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} and components.

It should however not become the default for all interactions, as some
of them still need to happen *precisely* within a given time frame,
which is a concept completely ignored by [contains]{.title-ref}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Most helpers in Hoot are available as methods of a
[contains]{.title-ref} instance, with (generally) the same shape and
API.
::::




--- SOURCE: developer/reference/frontend/unit_testing.md ---

show-content

show-toc

:   

# JavaScript Unit Testing

Writing unit tests is as important as writing the code itself: it helps
to ensure that the code is written according to a given specification
and that it remains correct as it evolves.

## Testing Framework

Testing the code starts with a testing framework. The framework provides
a level of abstraction that makes it possible to write tests in an easy
and efficient way. It also provides a set of tools to run the tests,
make assertions and report the results.

Odoo developers use a home-grown testing framework called
`HOOT (Hierarchically Organized
Odoo Tests)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}. The main reason for using a
custom framework is that it allows us to extend it based on our needs
(tags system, mocking of global objects, etc.).

On top of that framework we have built a set of tools to help us write
tests for the web client ([web_test_helpers]{.title-ref}), and a mock
server to simulate the server side ([mock_server]{.title-ref}).

You can find links to the reference of each of these parts below, as
well as a section filled with examples and best practices for writing
tests.

## Setup

Before learning how to write tests, it is good to start with the basics.
The following steps will ensure that your test files are properly picked
up by the test runner.

Note that in existing addons, most of these steps can be skipped since
the proper folder structure and asset bundles are probably set up.

1.  Writing files in the right **place**:

    > All JavaScript test files should be put under the
    > [/static/tests]{.title-ref} folder of the related addon (e.g.
    > `/web/static/tests/env.test.js`{.interpreted-text role="file"}).

2.  Using the right **name**:

    > Test files must end with `.test.js`{.interpreted-text
    > role="file"}. This is not only a convention, but a requirement for
    > test files to be picked up by the runner. All other JavaScript
    > files will be interpreted either as production code (i.e. the code
    > to be tested), or as test helper files (such as
    > [web_test_helpers]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/web/static/tests/web_test_helpers.js)).
    >
    > :::: note
    > ::: title
    > Note
    > :::
    >
    > It is to be noted that there is an exception for
    > `.hoot.js`{.interpreted-text role="file"} files, which are not
    > considered as test files, but as global modules for the whole test
    > run, while other JavaScript modules are re-created for each test
    > suite. Since the same instance of these modules will be running
    > for the whole test run, they follow strict constraints, such as
    > restricted imports, or advanced memory management techniques to
    > ensure no side-effects are affecting tests.
    > ::::

3.  Calling the files in the right **bundle**:

    > Test files, added in the right folder, must be included in the
    > [web.assets_unit_tests]{.title-ref} bundle. For ease of use, this
    > can be done with glob syntax to import all test and test helper
    > files:
    >
    > ``` python
    > # Unit test files
    > 'web.assets_unit_tests': [
    >     'my_addon/static/tests/**/*',
    > ],
    > ```

4.  Heading to the right **URL**:

    > To run tests, you can then go to the [/web/tests]{.title-ref} URL.
    >
    > :::: tip
    > ::: title
    > Tip
    > :::
    >
    > This page can be accessed through `fa-bug`{.interpreted-text
    > role="icon"} `Debug menu --> Run Unit Tests`{.interpreted-text
    > role="menuselection"}.
    > ::::

## Writing tests

After creating and including test files, it is time to write tests. You
may refer to the following documentation sections to learn about the
testing framework.

::: {.toctree titlesonly=""}
unit_testing/hoot unit_testing/web_helpers unit_testing/mock_server
:::

--- SOURCE: developer/reference/upgrades/upgrade_scripts.md ---

# Upgrade scripts

An upgrade script is a Python file containing a function called
`migrate`{.interpreted-text role="meth"}, which the upgrade process
invokes during the update of a module.

::: method
migrate(cr, version)

param cr
:   current database cursor

type cr
:   `~odoo.sql_db.Cursor`{.interpreted-text role="class"}

param str version
:   installed version of the module
:::

Typically, this function executes one or multiple SQL queries and can
also access Odoo\'s ORM, as well as the
`./upgrade_utils`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}.

## Writing upgrade scripts

Upgrade scripts follow a specific tree structure with a naming
convention which determines when they are executed.

The structure of an upgrade script path is
`$module/migrations/$version/{pre,post,end}-*.py`{.interpreted-text
role="file"}, where [\$module]{.title-ref} is the module for which the
script will run, [\$version]{.title-ref} is the full version of the
module (including Odoo\'s major version and the module\'s minor version)
and [{pre\|post\|end}-\*.py]{.title-ref} is the file that needs to be
executed. The file\'s name will determine the `phase
<upgrade-scripts/phases>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} and order in
which it is executed for that module and version.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

From Odoo 13 the top-level directory for the upgrade scripts can also be
named [upgrades]{.title-ref}. This naming is preferred since it has the
correct meaning: *migrate* can be confused with *moving out of Odoo*.
Thus `$module/upgrades/$version/`{.interpreted-text role="file"} is also
valid.
::::

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Upgrade scripts are only executed when the module is being updated.
Therefore, the module\'s minor version set in the
[\$version]{.title-ref} directory needs to be higher than the module\'s
installed version and equal or lower to the updated version of the
module.
::::

::: example
Directory structure of an upgrade script for a custom module named
[awesome_partner]{.title-ref} upgraded to version [2.0]{.title-ref} on
Odoo 17.

``` text
awesome_partner/
|-- migrations/
|   |-- 17.0.2.0/
|   |   |-- pre-exclamation.py
```

Two upgrade scripts examples with the content of the
`pre-exclamation.py`{.interpreted-text role="file"}, file adding \"!\"
at the end of partners\' names:

``` python
import logging

_logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


def migrate(cr, version):
    cr.execute("UPDATE res_partner SET name = name || '!'")
    _logger.info("Updated %s partners", cr.rowcount)
```

``` python
import logging
from odoo.upgrade import util

_logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


def migrate(cr, version):
    env = util.env(cr)

    partners = env["res.partner"].search([])
    for partner in partners:
        partner.name += "!"

    _logger.info("Updated %s partners", len(partners))
```

Note that in the second example, the script takes advantage of the
`./upgrade_utils`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} to access the ORM. Check
the documentation to find out more about this library.
:::

## Phases of upgrade scripts {#upgrade-scripts/phases}

The upgrade process consists of three phases for each version of each
module:

> 1.  The pre-phase, before the module is loaded.
> 2.  The post-phase, after the module and its dependencies are loaded
>     and updated.
> 3.  The end-phase, after all modules have been loaded and updated for
>     that version.

Upgrade scripts are grouped according to the first part of their
filenames into the corresponding phase. Within each phase, the files are
executed according to their lexical order.

::: admonition
Execution order of example scripts for one module in one version

1.  `pre-10-do_something.py`{.interpreted-text role="file"}
2.  `pre-20-something_else.py`{.interpreted-text role="file"}
3.  `post-do_something.py`{.interpreted-text role="file"}
4.  `post-something.py`{.interpreted-text role="file"}
5.  `end-01-migrate.py`{.interpreted-text role="file"}
6.  `end-migrate.py`{.interpreted-text role="file"}
:::




--- SOURCE: developer/reference/upgrades/upgrade_utils.md ---

# Upgrade utils

[Upgrade utils](https://github.com/odoo/upgrade-util/) is a library that
contains helper functions to facilitate the writing of upgrade scripts.
This library, used by Odoo for the upgrade scripts of standard modules,
provides reliability and helps speed up the upgrade process:

- The helper functions help make sure the data is consistent in the
  database.
- It takes care of indirect references of the updated records.
- Allows calling functions and avoid writing code, saving time and
  reducing development risks.
- Helpers allow to focus on what is important for the upgrade and not
  think of details.

## Installation

Clone the [Upgrade utils
repository](https://github.com/odoo/upgrade-util/) locally and start
`odoo` with the `src` directory prepended to the `--upgrade-path`
option.

``` console
$ ./odoo-bin --upgrade-path=/path/to/upgrade-util/src,/path/to/other/upgrade/script/directory [...]
```

On platforms where you do not manage Odoo yourself, you can install this
library via \`pip\`:

``` console
$ python3 -m pip install git+https://github.com/odoo/upgrade-util@master
```

On [Odoo.sh](https://www.odoo.sh/) it is recommended to add it to the
`requirements.txt`{.interpreted-text role="file"} of the custom
repository. For this, add the following line inside the file:

    odoo_upgrade @ git+https://github.com/odoo/upgrade-util@master

## Using upgrade utils

Once installed, the following packages are available for the upgrade
scripts:

- `odoo.upgrade.util`{.interpreted-text role="mod"}: the helper itself.
- `odoo.upgrade.testing`{.interpreted-text role="mod"}: base TestCase
  classes.

To use it in upgrade scripts, simply import it:

``` python
from odoo.upgrade import util


def migrate(cr, version):
   # Rest of the script
```

Now, the helper functions are available to be called through `util`.

## Util functions

Upgrade utils provides many useful functions to ease the upgrade
process. Here, we describe some of the most useful ones. Refer to the
[util folder](https://github.com/odoo/upgrade-util/tree/master/src/util)
for the comprehensive declaration of helper functions.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The `cr`{.interpreted-text role="attr"} parameter in util functions
always refers to the database cursor. Pass the one received as a
parameter in `migrate`{.interpreted-text role="meth"}. Not all functions
need this parameter.
::::

::: currentmodule
odoo.upgrade.util
:::

:::

# UI icons {#reference/user_interface/ui_icons}

Odoo\'s user interface mostly relies on [FontAwesome4
icons](https://fontawesome.com/v4/icons/).

To cover FontAwesome\'s lack of iconography for specific
functionalities, we designed our own icons:
`Odoo UI icons <ui/odoo-ui-icons>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"} and
`Odoo Spreadsheet icons
<ui/odoo-spreadsheet-icons>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

Directional icons have `RTL (right-to-left)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} adaptations which flip the icons by 180 degrees when an
`RTL (right-to-left)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} language is
selected.

## Odoo Spreadsheet icons {#ui/odoo-spreadsheet-icons}

The [Odoo
Spreadsheet]({GITHUB_PATH}/addons/spreadsheet/static/src/o_spreadsheet)
icons are defined as [\<svg\>]{.title-ref} elements and rendered using
QWeb [templates]({OWL_PATH}/doc/reference/templates.md).

``` html
<t t-name="o-spreadsheet-Icon.GLOBAL_FILTERS">
    <svg width="20" height="20" viewbox="0 0 20 20">

    </svg>
</t>
```
:::

--- SOURCE: developer/reference/user_interface/scss_inheritance.md ---

# SCSS inheritance

## Overview

Managing SCSS assets in Odoo is not as straightforward as it is in some
other environments, but it\'s highly efficient.

Modularity is key. The inheritance scheme described further allows Odoo
to:

- customize the Bootstrap CSS framework;
- handle two different webclient designs (Community and Enterprise);
- handle backend and frontend bundles separately (including the user\'s
  website design);
- contextually load only necessary assets;
- handle multiple color-schemes (e.g.: dark-mode);

## SCSS\'s [!default]{.title-ref} directive

\"Direct variables' overrides\" are technically possible in SCSS but may
lead to inconsistent results in complex environments like Odoo.

::: example
``` {.scss caption=":file:`library.scss`"}
$foo: red;
```

``` {.scss caption=":file:`customization_layer.scss`"}
$foo: blue; // -> Don't!
```
:::

Indeed, since the compilation process acts across different
interdependent bundles, re-assigning a variable in the \"wrong spot\"
may lead to unexpected cascading results.

SCSS provides several techniques to overcome these issues (e.g.:
[shadowing](https://sass-lang.com/documentation/variables#shadowing)),
but the most critical procedure in Odoo is the use of the
[!default]{.title-ref} flag.

When using the [!default]{.title-ref} flag, the compiler assigns a value
**only** if that variable is not yet defined.

As a result of this technique, the priority in which variables are
assigned matches the assets\' loading order.

::: example
``` {.scss caption=":file:`customization_layer.scss`"}
$foo: red !default;
```

``` {.scss caption=":file:`library.scss`"}
$foo: blue !default; // -> Already defined, line ignored.
$bar: black !default; // -> Not defined yet, value assigned.
```

``` {caption=":file:`component.scss`"}
.component {
   color: $foo; // -> 'color: red;'
   background: $bar; // -> 'background: black;'
}
```
:::

::: seealso
[!default]{.title-ref} flag on the [SASS
Documentation](https://sass-lang.com/documentation/variables#default-values)
:::

## Odoo\'s SCSS inheritance system

The following diagram conceptually illustrates the compilation order in
which the CSS and SCSS variables are defined.

``` text
↓ [Compilation starts]
⏐
↓ web.dark_mode_variables
⏐   ├─ Primary Variables
⏐   └─ Components Variables
⏐
↓ web._assets_primary_variables
⏐   ├─ Primary Variables (enterprise)
⏐   ├─ Components Variables (enterprise)
⏐   ├─ Primary Variables (community)
⏐   └─ Components Variables (community)
⏐
↓ web._assets_bootstrap
⏐
↓ web.assets_backend
⏐   ├─ ...
⏐   ├─ CSS variables definition
⏐   └─ CSS variables contextual adaptations
⏐
● [Visual result on screen]
```

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

This diagram is incomplete and does not match the current bundles\'
organization. Read more on
`asset bundles <reference/assets_bundle>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.
::::

--- SOURCE: developer/reference/user_interface/view_architectures/button_attribute_type.md ---

:::::: {.attribute noindex=""}
type

The type of the button indicating how it behaves. It can have two
different values:

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
object

Call a method on the view\'s model. The button\'s [name]{.title-ref} is
the method that is called with the current record ID and the current
[context]{.title-ref}.
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
action

Load and execute an [ir.actions]{.title-ref} action record. The
button\'s [name]{.title-ref} is the XMLID of the action to load. The
[context]{.title-ref} is extended with the view\'s model (as
[active_model]{.title-ref}) and with the current record (as
[active_id]{.title-ref}).
:::

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<button type=\"object\" name=\"action_create_new\" string=\"Create
document\"/\> \<button type=\"action\" name=\"addon.action_create_view\"
string=\"Create and Edit\"/\>
:::

requirement
:   Mandatory if the [special]{.title-ref} attribute is not set

type
:   str
::::::

--- SOURCE: developer/reference/user_interface/view_architectures/generic_attribute_class.md ---

::::: {.attribute noindex=""}
class

The [HTML class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML_attribute) to set on
the generated element.

The styling uses the [Bootstrap](https://getbootstrap.com) framework and
`UI icons
<reference/user_interface/ui_icons>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.
Common Odoo classes include:

- \`oe_inline\`: prevents the usual line break following fields, and
  limits their span;
- [oe_left]{.title-ref}, \`oe_right\`:
  [floats](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/float) the
  element to the corresponding direction;
- [oe_read_only]{.title-ref}, \`oe_edit_only\`: only displays the
  element in the corresponding form mode;
- \`oe_avatar\`: for image fields, displays images as an \"avatar\" (max
  90x90 square);
- \`oe_stat_button\`: defines a particular rendering to dynamically
  display information while being clickable to target an action.

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"fname\" class=\"oe_inline oe_left oe_avatar\"/\>
:::

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<button type=\"object\" name=\"ACTION\" class=\"oe_stat_button\" icon=\"FONT_AWESOME\" help=\"HELP\"\>

:   

    \<div class=\"o_field_widget o_stat_info\"\>

    :   \<span class=\"o_stat_value\"\>\<FIELD/\>\</span\> \<span
        class=\"o_stat_text\"\>TEXT\</span\>

    \</div\>

\</button\>
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str

default
:   [\'\']{.title-ref}
:::::




--- SOURCE: developer/reference/user_interface/view_architectures/generic_attribute_column_invisible.md ---

:::: {.attribute noindex=""}
column_invisible

Whether the column is visible ([False]{.title-ref}) or hidden
([True]{.title-ref}), as a Python expression that evaluates to a bool.

Unlike [invisible]{.title-ref}, it affects the entire column, and is
evaluated without the subtree values.

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"product_is_late\"
column_invisible=\"parent.has_late_products == False\"/\> \<button
type=\"object\" name=\"action_confirm\"
column_invisible=\"context.get(\'hide_confirm\')\"/\>
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   `Python expression <reference/view_architectures/python_expression>`{.interpreted-text
    role="ref"}

default
:   [False]{.title-ref}
::::




--- SOURCE: developer/reference/user_interface/view_architectures/generic_attribute_groups.md ---

:::: {.attribute noindex=""}
groups

The comma-separated list of user groups to whom the element is
displayed. Users who do not belong to at least one of these groups are
unable to see the element. Groups can be prefixed with the negative
[!]{.title-ref} operator to exclude them.

::: example
``` xml
<field name="FIELD_NAME" groups="base.group_no_one,!base.group_multi_company"/>
```
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str

default
:   [\'\']{.title-ref}
::::




--- SOURCE: developer/reference/user_interface/view_architectures/generic_attribute_invisible.md ---

:::::: {.attribute noindex=""}
invisible

Whether the element is visible ([False]{.title-ref}) or hidden
([True]{.title-ref}), as a Python expression that evaluates to a bool.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

There are two uses for the [invisible]{.title-ref} attribute:

- Usability: to avoid overloading the view and to make it easier for the
  user to read, depending on the content.
- Technical: a field must be present (invisible is enough) in the view
  to be used in a Python expression.
::::

::: example
``` xml
<field name="fname_b" invisible="fname_c != 3 and fname_a == parent.fname_d"/>
<group invisible="fname_c != 4">
    <field name="fname_c"/>
    <field name="fname_d"/>
<group>
```
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   `Python expression <reference/view_architectures/python_expression>`{.interpreted-text
    role="ref"}

default
:   [False]{.title-ref}
::::::

--- SOURCE: developer/reference/user_interface/view_architectures/root_attribute_sample.md ---

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
sample

Whether the view should be populated with a set of sample records if
none are found for the current model.

These fake records have heuristics for certain field names/models. For
example, a field [display_name]{.title-ref} on the model
[res.users]{.title-ref} will be populated with sample people names,
while an [email]{.title-ref} field will be in the form
[firstname.lastname@sample.demo]{.title-ref}.

The user is unable to interact with these data, and they will be
discarded as soon as an action is performed (record created, column
added, etc.).

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   bool

default
:   [False]{.title-ref}
:::

--- SOURCE: developer/reference/user_interface/view_architectures.md ---

custom-css
:   showcase_tables.css

# View architectures

## Generic architecture

The architecture of a view is defined by XML data interpreted by the
JavaScript framework.

For most views, there is a `\*.rng`{.interpreted-text role="file"} file
defining the attributes and possible architectures. Some views are not
ruled by such a file either because they accept HTML content, or for
performance reasons.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The current context and user access rights may impact the view
abilities.
::::

::: seealso
`view_records`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::

## Python expression {#reference/view_architectures/python_expression}

When evaluating node attributes, e.g. the [readonly]{.title-ref}
modifier, it is possible to provide a **Python expression** that will be
executed in an environment that has access to the following variables:

- The names of all fields present in the current view, containing the
  value of the current record, except for [column_invisible]{.title-ref}
  in
  `list view <reference/view_architectures/list/field>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}; relational fields are given as a list of IDs;
- The ID of the current record;
- \`parent\`: the record that refers to the container; only inside
  sub-views of `relational
  fields <studio/fields/relational-fields>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"};
- \`context (dict)\`: the current view\'s context;
- \`uid (int)\`: the id of the current user;
- \`today (str)\`: the current local date in the
  [YYYY-MM-DD]{.title-ref} format;
- \`now (str)\`: the current local datetime in the [YYYY-MM-DD
  hh:mm:ss]{.title-ref} format.

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"field_a\" readonly=\"True\"/\> \<field name=\"field_b\"
invisible=\"context.get(\'show_me\') and field_a == 4\"/\>
:::

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"field_a\"/\> \<field name=\"x2m\"\> \<!\-- sub-view \--\>
\<form\> \<field name=\"field_b\" invisible=\"parent.field_a\"/\>
\</form\> \</field\>
:::

## Form {#reference/view_architectures/form}

Form views are used to display the data from a single record. They are
composed of regular [HTML](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML) with
additional semantic and structural components.

The root element of form views is [form]{.title-ref}.

``` xml
<form>
    ...
</form>
```

### Root attributes {#reference/view_architectures/form/root}

Optional attributes can be added to the root element [form]{.title-ref}
to customize the view.

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
string

The view title. It is displayed only if you open an action that has no
name and whose target is [new]{.title-ref} (opening a dialog).

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str

default
:   [\'\']{.title-ref}
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
create

Disable/enable record creation on the view.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   bool

default
:   [True]{.title-ref}
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
edit

Disable/enable record edition on the view.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   bool

default
:   [True]{.title-ref}
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
duplicate

Disable/enable record duplication on the view through the **Action**
dropdown.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   bool

default
:   [True]{.title-ref}
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
delete

Disable/enable record deletion on the view through the
`Action`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dropdown.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   bool

default
:   [True]{.title-ref}
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
js_class

The name of the JavaScript component the webclient will instantiate
instead of the form view.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str

default
:   [\'\']{.title-ref}
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
disable_autofocus

Disable automatic focusing on the first field in the view.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   bool

default
:   [False]{.title-ref}
:::

### Semantic components {#reference/view_architectures/form/semantic}

Semantic components tie into the Odoo system and allow interaction with
it.

Form views accept the following children semantic components: `field
<reference/view_architectures/form/field>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"},
`label <reference/view_architectures/form/label>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"},
`button <reference/view_architectures/form/button>`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"},
`reference/view_architectures/form/chatter`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}, and
`reference/view_architectures/form/attachment`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}.

Placeholders are denoted in all caps.

#### \`field\`: display field values {#reference/view_architectures/form/field}

The [field]{.title-ref} element renders (and allows editing of,
possibly) a single field of the current record.

Using the same field multiple times in a form view is supported, and the
fields can receive different values for the [invisible]{.title-ref} and
[readonly]{.title-ref} attributes. These fields may have the same values
but can be displayed differently. However, the behavior is not
guaranteed when several fields exist with different values for the
[required]{.title-ref} attribute.

``` xml
<form>
    <field name="FIELD_NAME"/>
</form>
```

The [field]{.title-ref} element can have the following attributes:

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
name

The name of the field to render.

requirement
:   Mandatory

type
:   str
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
widget

The widget used to represent the field. The selected widget can change
the way the field is rendered and/or the way it can be edited. It refers
to a Javascript implementation (an Owl component) registered to the
[fields]{.title-ref} registry.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
id

The node id. Useful when there are several occurrences of the same field
in the view (see
`reference/view_architectures/form/label`{.interpreted-text
role="ref"}).

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str

default
:   The field name
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
string

The label of the field.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str

default
:   The [string]{.title-ref} attribute of the model\'s field
:::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
help

The tooltip displayed when hovering the field or its label.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str

default
:   [\'\']{.title-ref}
:::

:::: {.attribute noindex=""}
options

The configuration options for the field\'s widget (including default
widgets), as a Python expression that evaluates to a dict.

For relation fields, the following options are available:
[no_create]{.title-ref}, [no_quick_create]{.title-ref},
[no_open]{.title-ref}, and [no_create_edit]{.title-ref}.

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"tag_ids\" widget=\"many2many_tags\"
options=\"{\'color_field\': \'FIELD_NAME\', \'no_quick_create\':
True}\"/\>
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   `Python expression <reference/view_architectures/python_expression>`{.interpreted-text
    role="ref"}

default
:   [{}]{.title-ref}
::::

:::: {.attribute noindex=""}
readonly

Whether the field can be modified by the user ([False]{.title-ref}) or
is read-only ([True]{.title-ref}), as a Python expression that evaluates
to a bool.

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"fname_a\" readonly=\"True\"/\> \<field name=\"fname_b\"
readonly=\"name_a in \[fname_b, parent.fname_d\]\"/\>
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   `Python expression <reference/view_architectures/python_expression>`{.interpreted-text
    role="ref"}

default
:   [False]{.title-ref}
::::

:::: {.attribute noindex=""}
required

Whether the field can be left empty ([False]{.title-ref}) or must be set
([True]{.title-ref}), as a Python expression that evaluates to a bool.

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"fname_a\" required=\"True\"/\> \<field name=\"fname_b\"
required=\"fname_c != 3\"/\>
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   `Python expression <reference/view_architectures/python_expression>`{.interpreted-text
    role="ref"}

default
:   [False]{.title-ref}
::::

:::::: {.attribute noindex=""}
invisible

Whether the element is visible ([False]{.title-ref}) or hidden
([True]{.title-ref}), as a Python expression that evaluates to a bool.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

There are two uses for the [invisible]{.title-ref} attribute:

- Usability: to avoid overloading the view and to make it easier for the
  user to read, depending on the content.
- Technical: a field must be present (invisible is enough) in the view
  to be used in a Python expression.
::::

::: example
``` xml
<field name="fname_b" invisible="fname_c != 3 and fname_a == parent.fname_d"/>
<group invisible="fname_c != 4">
    <field name="fname_c"/>
    <field name="fname_d"/>
<group>
```
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   `Python expression <reference/view_architectures/python_expression>`{.interpreted-text
    role="ref"}

default
:   [False]{.title-ref}
::::::

:::: {.attribute noindex=""}
groups

The comma-separated list of user groups to whom the element is
displayed. Users who do not belong to at least one of these groups are
unable to see the element. Groups can be prefixed with the negative
[!]{.title-ref} operator to exclude them.

::: example
``` xml
<field name="FIELD_NAME" groups="base.group_no_one,!base.group_multi_company"/>
```
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   str

default
:   [\'\']{.title-ref}
::::

:::: {.attribute noindex=""}
domain

The filters to apply when displaying existing records for selection, as
a Python expression that evaluates to a
`domain <reference/orm/domains>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}.

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"fname\" domain=\"\[(\'fname_a\', \'=\',
parent.fname_b)\]\"/\>
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   `Python expression <reference/view_architectures/python_expression>`{.interpreted-text
    role="ref"}

default
:   [\[\]]{.title-ref}

scope
:   Relational fields
::::

::::: {.attribute noindex=""}
context

::: todo
extensive documentation on all the magic context values (TYPE_view_ref,
group_by, search_default_FIELD\...
:::

The context to use when fetching possible values and creating or
searching records, as a Python expression that evaluates to a dict.

::: example
.. code-block:: xml

\<field name=\"fname\" context=\"{

:   \'TYPE_view_ref\': \'ADDON.MODEL_view_TYPE\', \'group_by\':
    \'FIELD_NAME\', \'default_FIELD_NAME\': ANY,
    \'search_default_FIELD_NAME\': True, \'OTHER_BUSINESS_KEY\': ANY,
    }\"/\>
:::

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   `Python expression <reference/view_architectures/python_expression>`{.interpreted-text
    role="ref"}

default
:   [{}]{.title-ref}

scope
:   Relational fields
:::::

::: {.attribute noindex=""}
nolabel

Whether the field label should be hidden.

requirement
:   Optional

type
:   bool

default
:   [False]{.title-ref}

scope
